CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: The provider drains fluid from an abscess, cyst, or hematoma, from the vestibule or anterior most portion of the oral cavity of the patient’s mouth. This procedure involves a simple drainage.

Excision Procedures on the Tongue and Floor of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider makes an incision in the posterior one third of the tongue and excises the affected tissues for the purpose of biopsy.
CPT.explanation: 41105 pertains to biopsy of oral mucosa and/or lesion; vestibule of mouth.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Tongue and Floor of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider excises a lesion from the posterior one thirds of the tongue.
CPT.explanation: 41113 pertains to excision of lesion of floor of mouth.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: The provider removes a foreign body present in the vestibule or anterior most portion of the oral cavity of the patient’s mouth. This procedure involves a simple removal.
CPT.explanation: 40804 pertains to excision of lesion, vestibule of mouth (mucocele).

CPT.description: Incision and Drainage Procedures on the Skin, Subcutaneous and Accessory Structures Summary: The provider open (incises) and drains the contents of a pilonidal cyst.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 10080 – Incision & Drainage, Pilonidal Cyst; Simple 

WHEN TO USE 10080  
• Diagnosis MUST say pilonidal cyst, pilonidal abscess, or pilonidal sinus WITH acute abscess.  
• Anatomic site is LIMITED to the sacrococcygeal/intergluteal (natal) cleft.  
• The surgeon makes a SINGLE scalpel incision, breaks up any loculations with a probe, washes out pus/hair/debris, and applies a dressing.  
• ONLY drainage is performed; nothing is cut away and no packing is left behind.  
• No undermining, marsupialization, flap, or wide dissection is done—this is what CPT calls “simple.”

WHAT 10080 DOES NOT COVER  
× Abscesses anywhere else (thigh, axilla, trunk, buttock cheek, etc.) → 10060 (simple) or 10061 (complicated).  
× Needle-only aspiration (no scalpel) → 10160.  
× Definitive removal (excision) of a pilonidal cyst or its sinus tracts → 11770 (simple excision), 11771 (extensive excision), 11772 (excision with flap/complex closure).  
× Complex/multiloculated pilonidal drainage requiring wide dissection, marsupialization, or packing left in place → 10081 (if the payer still recognizes it) or unlisted code 17999 per payer policy.

COMMON MISCONCEPTIONS  
• “It’s on the buttock, so it must be 10080.” No—the lesion has to be in the natal cleft; anything on the buttock cheek or thigh is coded like any other skin abscess (10060/10061).  
• “Simple drainage of a pilonidal cyst gets coded the same as excision.” False—drainage = 10080; excision = 11770-11772.  
• Confusing “simple” in 10060 with “simple” in 10080. Body site drives the choice: natal cleft → 10080; any other site → 10060/10061.

QUICK DECISION GRID  
Natal cleft + scalpel incision + drainage only → 10080  
Other site + scalpel incision + drainage only → 10060 (or 10061 if complicated)  
Needle aspiration only → 10160  
Removal (excision) of a pilonidal cyst/sinus → 11770-11772

CPT.description: Fine Needle Aspiration Biopsy Procedures Summary: The provider performs a fine needle aspiration (FNA), a diagnostic procedure that involves collecting a small number of cells, a small amount of tissue, or fluid from a cyst or mass using a specialized needle and syringe. Report this code for the first lesion biopsied.

Incision and Drainage Procedures on the Skin, Subcutaneous and Accessory Structures Summary: The provider incises the area of abscess and drains the collection of pus from a lesion, such as a carbuncle, hidradenitis, cyst, furuncle, or paronychia, with the help of surgical instruments. A simple incision and drainage usually involves a single incision of an abscess situated just below the skin's surface.
CPT.explanation: 10060 is the CPT code for incision and drainage of abscess (e.g., carbuncle, suppurative hidradenitis, cutaneous or subcutaneous abscess, cyst, furuncle, or paronychia); simple or single.

CPT.description: Incision and Drainage Procedures on the Skin, Subcutaneous and Accessory Structures Summary: The provider inserts a needle into a fluid deposit area on the skin and aspirates fluid or pus to obtain a culture.
No Summary found for this code
CPT.explanation:
CPT 20005 — Incision & Drainage of DEEP Soft-Tissue ABSCESS  
(Subfascial or Intramuscular), any anatomic site

USE THIS CODE ONLY WHEN ALL FOUR CONDITIONS ARE MET  
1. The cavity contains pus (abscess, purulent fluid, suppurative collection, empyema).  
2. The surgeon passes THROUGH the deep (investing) fascia to reach the collection; it lies inside muscle or immediately beneath fascia.  
3. The surgeon merely drains the cavity (incision, break-up of loculations, irrigation ± drain placement). The wall of the cavity is left in place; nothing is excised en bloc.  
4. No bone is entered or debrided (entering cortex or curetting bone = 20002).

WHAT 20005 IS NOT  
• NOT for hematoma or seroma (sterile blood/serum).  
  – Upper arm/elbow hematoma or seroma → 20010  
  – Leg/ankle hematoma or seroma → 27603  
  – Superficial hematoma/seroma → 10140  
• NOT for superficial skin/subcutaneous abscess → 10060 (simple) or 10061 (complicated).  
• NOT for intra-osseous (bone) abscess → 20002.  
• NOT for traumatic open fracture/dislocation wounds → 11010-11012 or 11042-11047.  
• NOT for complete excision of a cyst, lipoma, ganglion, or any mass—infected or not. Once the entire lesion is removed, code as a soft-tissue tumor excision per anatomic site (e.g., 24071-24079 for arm).

CYST-SPECIFIC RULES  
• Cyst only LANCED/DRAINED and yields pus  
  – Superficial → 10060/10061  
  – Deep (subfascial/intramuscular) → 20005  
• Cyst COMPLETELY EXCISED (wall removed)  
  – Code as soft-tissue tumor excision (depth & size drive code). Infection does not change this.

COMMON MISCONCEPTIONS  
✘ Depth alone does not justify 20005; the content must be purulent.  
✘ “Incision & drainage” is not “excision.” Removing the entire wall converts the service to a tumor-excision code.  
✘ 20005 is never used for blood or serum collections, regardless of depth.

AT-A-GLANCE COMPARISON  
10060-10061  Superficial abscess (pus) I&D  
10140         Superficial hematoma/seroma (blood/serum) I&D  
20002         Bone abscess (pus in bone) I&D  
20005         Deep subfascial/intramuscular abscess (pus) I&D  
20010         Arm/elbow hematoma/seroma (blood/serum) I&D  
27603         Leg/ankle hematoma/seroma (blood/serum) I&D

Mnemonic: “20005 = DEEP PUS ONLY — no blood, no bone, no full-mass removal.”

CPT.description: CPT code 20055 - Not found on AAPC website. This may be a test code or requires specialized knowledge. Please research this code further.
No Summary found for this code
CPT.explanation:
CPT 20010  
Incision & Drainage of a NON-purulent fluid collection (seroma, hematoma, other sterile fluid) – UPPER ARM / ELBOW ONLY

USE 20010 WHEN ALL THREE CONDITIONS ARE MET  
1. ANATOMIC SITE – The skin incision is in the upper arm or elbow region (above the olecranon tip, below the inferior border of the deltoid). Any other body part = NOT 20010.  
2. PATHOLOGY – The material removed is clear, serous, bloody, or otherwise NON-infected. If pus or cellulitis is present, use the “infected abscess” code (20005).  
3. SURGICAL WORK – The surgeon (or other qualified professional) merely opens the site, evacuates fluid, breaks up loculations, irrigates, may place a drain, and closes the wound. NO solid tissue (cyst wall, bursa, capsule, tumor, etc.) is excised.

CYST-SPECIFIC RULES  
• Cyst OPENED and contents drained; cyst wall or capsule left in situ → treat as a sterile fluid collection. Use 20010 only if the incision is in the upper arm/elbow.  
• Cyst REMOVED in its entirety (wall/capsule excised) → this is an excision, not an I&D. Select the appropriate integumentary or musculoskeletal excision code, never 20010.

DO NOT USE 20010 FOR  
• Any purulent/infected abscess (same area) → 20005.  
• Different anatomic sites:  
 – Forearm/Wrist 20011  
 – Rib Cage 20015  
 – Thigh/Knee 20016  
 – Lower Leg/Ankle 20017  
 – Foot 20018  
• Superficial skin I&D (10040-10060 series).  
• Total excision of a cyst, bursa, or other structure.

COMMON MISCONCEPTIONS (and the correct rule)  
✘ “20010 is the generic seroma code.” → No. It is LIMITED to upper arm/elbow.  
✘ “Use 20010 if there’s no pus anywhere on the body.” → No. Site must match.  
✘ “Opening a cyst is always 20010.” → Only if nothing except FLUID is removed AND the site is upper arm/elbow.

ONE-SENTENCE MEMORY HOOK  
Non-infected fluid in the upper arm/elbow? Slice, drain, and close—code 20010.

CPT.description: CPT code 20020 - Not found on AAPC website. This may be a test code or requires specialized knowledge. Please research this code further.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 20020 – Incision and Removal of Foreign Body, Subcutaneous Tissues; Simple

Plain-English meaning  
• A short skin incision is made just deep enough to reach the subcutaneous fat.  
• The surgeon locates and lifts out a piece of material that is NOT part of the patient (wood splinter, glass, BB, bullet fragment, plastic shard, etc.).  
• No dissection enters fascia, muscle, tendon, joint, or bone, and no native tissue is cut out except the minimal track needed to reach the object.  
• Once the foreign material is removed, the wound is irrigated and closed. Nothing else is treated.

When 20020 IS appropriate  
✓ Object = exogenous (foreign) material.  
✓ Location = subcutaneous layer only.  
✓ Procedure = simple cut → extract object → close.  
✓ Operation’s sole purpose = remove that object.

When 20020 is NOT appropriate (and what to choose instead)  
✘ Cyst, lipoma, ganglion, sebaceous or any other lesion made of the patient’s own cells.  
 → Code as a benign-lesion excision by anatomic site/size (e.g., 11400-11446 for skin, 24071-24076 for soft tissue of upper arm, etc.).  
✘ Abscess, hematoma, seroma drainage.  
 → 20005 (deep abscess) or 20010 (simple hematoma/seroma).  
✘ Exploration of traumatic wounds.  
 → 20100-20103.  
✘ Removal of objects embedded in muscle, tendon, joint, or bone, or cases needing extensive dissection.  
 → 20670-20680 or other musculoskeletal codes.  
✘ Any incidental foreign-body removal done during another primary procedure.  
 → Do not report 20020 separately.

Key misconception to avoid  
• “Cyst” ≠ foreign body. Excision of ANY cyst is never billed with 20020. Use the correct lesion-excision code instead.

Quick decision rule  
Foreign object? Subcutaneous? Simple extraction only? → 20020.  
Patient’s own tissue (cyst/mass) or fluid collection? → Different code; never 20020.

CPT.description: Chemistry Procedures Summary: Sugar in the bloodstream can get attached to the hemoglobin in red blood cells. Once the sugar is attached, it stays there for the lifetime of the red blood cell (around 120 days or over 3 months). The higher the amount of blood sugar, the more the quantity of sugar attached to the blood cells. This A1C test measures the amount of sugar sticking to the red blood cells, displaying the result as a percentage. This gives the physician an understanding about the blood sugar level of the patient for the preceding three months. A normal, healthy person should have A1C level below 7%.
CPT.explanation: Code 83036 is for the Hemoglobin A1c test. The other codes are not specific to the Hemoglobin A1c test and represent different laboratory tests.

CPT.description: Chemistry Procedures Summary: The analyst tests for the presence of hemoglobin F, typically in a whole blood sample. The amount is usually very low, except in the newborn infant, in whom almost all the hemoglobin is type F.

CPT code 83034 - Not found on AAPC website. This may be a test code or requires specialized knowledge. Please research this code further.

Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: This is a procedure involving surgical removal of a part of one of the two lobes the thyroid gland is divided into. The provider may perform the procedure with or without surgical removal of the isthmus, the tissue connecting the two lobes of the thyroid gland in the middle.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60210, refers to a partial thyroidectomy. While 60212 describes a complete thyroid lobectomy, 60100 is for a thyroid biopsy, and 60225 pertains to a thyroid lobectomy with contralateral subtotal lobectomy. In this scenario, only a partial thyroidectomy was performed, making 60210 the appropriate code.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: The procedure involves surgical removal of a part of one lobe of the thyroid gland and most of the portion of the other lobe of the thyroid gland. The provider also performs surgical removal of the isthmus, the tissue connecting the two lobes of the thyroid gland in the middle.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60100, refers to a fine needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid. In contrast, 60240 describes a complete thyroidectomy, 60220 is for a thyroid lobectomy, and 60212 is for a complete thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy. The question explicitly mentions a biopsy, making 60100 the right choice.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: This is a procedure involving complete surgical removal of one of the two lobes the thyroid gland is divided into. The provider may perform the procedure with or without surgical removal of the isthmus, the tissue connecting the two lobes of the thyroid gland in the middle.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60100, refers to a fine needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid. In contrast, 60240 describes a complete thyroidectomy, 60220 is for a thyroid lobectomy, and 60212 is for a complete thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy. The question explicitly mentions a biopsy, making 60100 the right choice.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: The procedure involves surgical removal of one whole lobe of the thyroid gland and most of the other lobe of the thyroid gland. The provider also performs surgical removal of the isthmus, the tissue connecting the two lobes of the thyroid gland in the middle.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60210, refers to a partial thyroidectomy. While 60212 describes a complete thyroid lobectomy, 60100 is for a thyroid biopsy, and 60225 pertains to a thyroid lobectomy with contralateral subtotal lobectomy. In this scenario, only a partial thyroidectomy was performed, making 60210 the appropriate code.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: The provider examines the kidney for diagnostic purposes, without any curative surgical intervention, such as inspection for hemorrhage, urinary leakage, or tissue damage due to trauma.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 50010 – Renal exploration, retroperitoneal, open (includes control of renal blood vessels)

When to use  
• The surgeon performs an OPEN flank or transabdominal incision solely to inspect the kidney and its pedicle: evaluate unexplained hemorrhage, urine leak, traumatic laceration, pedicle injury, or other pathology that cannot be clarified by imaging alone.  
• Limited, incidental actions may be taken during the exploration (evacuation of hematoma, ligation of bleeding vessels, drainage, minor repair, procurement of a small biopsy).  
• The kidney is left in place; no mass, cyst, or segment of parenchyma is definitively removed.

Common misconceptions  
✘ 50010 is NOT an imaging or catheter-based study. Do not report it for renal angiography (use selective arterial catheterization 36245 ± renal arteriography 75722) or for antegrade nephrostogram/ureterogram (50398).  
✘ It is NOT a nephrectomy (use 50220 for total, 50234-50236 for partial).  
✘ It is NOT a biopsy-only procedure (percutaneous 50200, open 50205).  
✘ It is NOT the code for excision, marsupialization, or decortication of renal cysts; those services are reported with 50280/50285 (open) or 50541-50542 (laparoscopic/robotic).

Cyst-related guidance  
• If the operation stops after visual inspection of a cyst without removing or marsupializing it, 50010 may be appropriate.  
• Once the surgeon excises, decorticates, or marsupializes a renal cyst, bill the definitive cyst procedure code (e.g., 50280, 50285, 50541) instead of—or in lieu of—50010.  
• Do NOT append 50010 in addition to a cyst-excision code; exploratory work is inherent to the definitive cyst procedure.

Summary  
Choose 50010 only for an open diagnostic/therapeutic RENAL EXPLORATION that does not culminate in cyst removal, nephrectomy, or isolated biopsy and that is unrelated to vascular or collecting-system contrast studies.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: The provider drains an abscess from the kidney (renal) or the area surrounding the kidney (perirenal) with an open approach.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50543, refers to a percutaneous nephrostolithotomy or pyelostolithotomy. The other codes are: 50010 - Renal exploratory surgery, 50020 - Renal abscess drainage, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: In this procedure.  A physician inserts a collection needle into the kidney to collect a sample for further diagnostic biopsy.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 51600, pertains to cystography. The other codes are: 50395 - Injection procedure for nephrostogram or ureterogram, 50250 - Ablation, renal tumor, unilateral, percutaneous, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.description: Laparoscopic Procedures on the Kidney Summary: The provider uses a surgical laparoscopic technique to remove part of a kidney.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50543, refers to a percutaneous nephrostolithotomy or pyelostolithotomy. The other codes are: 50010 - Renal exploratory surgery, 50020 - Renal abscess drainage, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: Nephrectomy is a surgical procedure for removal of a kidney or part of a kidney.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50200, refers to a renal biopsy. The other codes are: 50220 - Nephrectomy, 50225 - Delayed nephrostogram, and 50230 - Nephrectomy, partial.

CPT.description: No Summary found for this code
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50010, refers to renal exploratory surgery. 50220 describes a nephrectomy, 50200 is for a renal biopsy, and 50398 describes an injection procedure for antegrade nephrostogram and/or ureterogram.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Nose Summary: In this procedure, the provider aspirates the excess fluid from within the nasal cavity, which may be due to an abscess or hematoma.
Excision Procedures on the Nose Summary: This CPT code is for a submucous resection of the inferior turbinate (partial or complete by any method).
Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity to examine the structures of the nasal cavity on one or both sides.
CPT.explanation: 31231 is the CPT code for nasal endoscopy, diagnostic, unilateral or bilateral (separate procedure).

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity. She examines the nasal contents. The provider then performs a nasal biopsy, polypectomy, or debridement.
CPT code 20016 - Not found on AAPC website. This may be a test code or requires specialized knowledge. Please research this code further.
Incision Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider makes an intranasal incision. The provider then uses cutting forceps to perform a middle meatal sinusotomy.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity. He then gains access to the maxillary sinus through a cut in the uncinate process. The provider opens the maxillary sinus.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 31256  
Endoscopic Maxillary Antrostomy / Sinusotomy – “Door-widening ONLY”

1. WHAT THE SURGEON ACTUALLY DOES
• Introduces a rigid or flexible nasal endoscope to the middle meatus.  
• Identifies the NATURAL MAXILLARY OSTIUM.  
• Widens the ostium by shaving a rim of mucosa ± a sliver of bone.  
• Scope NEVER goes beyond the ostial edge; NOTHING is removed from the maxillary sinus cavity.  
• Goal: create a bigger “door” so the sinus will drain/ventilate better, then withdraw the scope.

2. THE “CYST / POLYP / MUCOCELE” RULE
• If a very small lesion sitting right on the ostial rim must be nicked, shaved, or curetted SOLELY to open the door, stay with 31256.  
• The moment the surgeon ENTERS the sinus cavity to scoop, debride, or remove any substantial cyst, polypoid tissue, fungus, pus, tumor, or debris, you must convert to 31267 (antrostomy WITH tissue removal).

3. USE 31256 WHEN DOCUMENTATION SAYS
✓ “Endoscopic maxillary antrostomy performed; ostium enlarged only.”  
✓ “Minimal mucosal trimming; no tissue sent to pathology.”  
✓ “Scope not advanced into the sinus.”  
✓ Part of multi-sinus FESS where ONLY the maxillary ostium is opened and no intramaxillary work is done.

4. DO NOT USE 31256 FOR
× Endoscopic anterior/posterior ethmoidectomy → 31255 (classic “complete FESS”).  
× Endoscopic antrostomy WITH any intrasinus tissue removal → 31267.  
× Frontal sinusotomy → 31276.  
× Sphenoidotomy without/with tissue removal → 31287 / 31288.  
× Non-endoscopic (intranasal) antrostomy → 31020.

5. COMMON MISCONCEPTIONS
• “FESS” does NOT automatically equal 31255 or 31267. Verify which sinus was treated and whether material was removed.  
• Phrases like “sinus cleared” or “blockage relieved” are NOT enough—look for explicit words such as “debrided,” “removed from within,” “tissue sent to pathology” to justify 31267.  
• Trimming a tiny cyst on the ostial lip is still 31256 because the instrument never enters the sinus cavity proper.

6. MEMORY HOOK
31256 = “Scope in, enlarge the door, step out—nothing taken from the room.”

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity and creates an opening in the sphenoid sinus.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity. The provider widens the sphenoid sinus opening. He then removes tissues from the sphenoid sinus.
Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: The procedure involves surgical removal of the entire thyroid gland.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60100, refers to a fine needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid. In contrast, 60240 describes a complete thyroidectomy, 60220 is for a thyroid lobectomy, and 60212 is for a complete thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy. The question explicitly mentions a biopsy, making 60100 the right choice.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: This is a diagnostic procedure in which the provider removes a tissue sample from the thyroid gland, typically under imaging guidance, using an automatic, spring–powered core needle.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60100, refers to a fine needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid. In contrast, 60240 describes a complete thyroidectomy, 60220 is for a thyroid lobectomy, and 60212 is for a complete thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy. The question explicitly mentions a biopsy, making 60100 the right choice.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Parathyroid, Thymus, Adrenal Glands, Pancreas, and Carotid Body Summary: In the traditional procedure of parathyroid exploration, the provider surgically visualizes and screens the parathyroid glands for pathology based on their appearance and relative size. He may then perform parathyroidectomy, which is surgical removal of one or more parathyroid glands as indicated. The glands are a set of four small glands situated on the rear of the four corners of the butterfly shaped thyroid gland.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60500, refers to a parathyroidectomy. While 60212 and 60240 are associated with thyroid procedures (thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy and total thyroidectomy respectively), 60100 is for a thyroid biopsy. The scenario specifies a procedure on the parathyroid, making 60500 the accurate code.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Upper Extremities Summary: The provider takes at least three X–ray images of a patient’s complete wrist to check for any fracture, swelling, or reason of pain in the wrist area.
CPT.explanation: Code 73110 pertains to radiologic examination of the wrist with a minimum of three views. 73100 is for two views, 73120 is for one view, and 73115 is for a post-reduction (after fixing a dislocation or fracture) examination.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Upper Extremities Summary: In this procedure, the provider takes two X–ray images of a patient’s wrist to check for any fracture, swelling, or reason of pain in the wrist area.
CPT.explanation: Code 73110 pertains to radiologic examination of the wrist with a minimum of three views. 73100 is for two views, 73120 is for one view, and 73115 is for a post-reduction (after fixing a dislocation or fracture) examination.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Upper Extremities Summary: X–rays of the extremities have been performed to assess injury, fracture, arthritis, bone spurs, tumors, or congenital abnormalities. Extremity X–rays include the hand, wrist, arm, foot, ankle, hip, leg, shoulder, or knee. X–rays of the affected site focus on the specific area that is injured or damaged.
CPT.explanation: Code 73110 pertains to radiologic examination of the wrist with a minimum of three views. 73100 is for two views, 73120 is for one view, and 73115 is for a post-reduction (after fixing a dislocation or fracture) examination.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Upper Extremities Summary: In this procedure, the provider performs imaging supervision and interpretation for a wrist joint study. The provider injects contrast material or air into the patient’s wrist joint and takes a series of X–rays as it flows through the joint to evaluate the different joint structures for conditions such as arthritis, adhesive capsulitis, or a frozen joint, tears, or abnormalities of the cartilage. Report this code to represent only imaging supervision and interpretation for this procedure.
CPT.explanation: Code 73110 pertains to radiologic examination of the wrist with a minimum of three views. 73100 is for two views, 73120 is for one view, and 73115 is for a post-reduction (after fixing a dislocation or fracture) examination.

CPT.description: Excision and Destruction Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: The provider excises a lesion or area of damaged or diseased tissue of the mucosa, a membrane lining the anterior most part of the mouth, and the submucosa, the layer beneath the mucosa. This procedure involves a simple repair of the surgical wound.
Excision Procedures on the Tongue and Floor of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider performs an incision in the floor of the mouth and excises tissue for the purpose of biopsy.

Excision and Destruction Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider removes the labial or buccal frenum, each of which is a membrane structure in the mouth. Labial refers to the lip and buccal refers to the cheek.

Endoscopy-Cystoscopy, Urethroscopy, Cystourethroscopy Procedures on the Bladder Summary: In this procedure, the provider performs an examination of the interior of the bladder, the urethra, and the ureteric openings by means of a cystourethroscope, a thin flexible or rigid tube with a camera on one end.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 52000, pertains to cystourethroscopy. The other codes are: 50250 - Ablation, renal tumor, unilateral, percutaneous, 50200 - Renal biopsy, and 50395 - Injection procedure for nephrostogram or ureterogram.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: Cryoablation or cryosurgery is a procedure in which very low temperatures are used to destroy a mass lesion, tumor cells, or cancer cells by freezing them. In this procedure cold is introduced to the intended target through a probe containing liquid nitrogen that is inserted into the kidney.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 51600, pertains to cystography. The other codes are: 50395 - Injection procedure for nephrostogram or ureterogram, 50250 - Ablation, renal tumor, unilateral, percutaneous, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.explanation: The correct code, 51600, pertains to cystography. The other codes are: 50395 - Injection procedure for nephrostogram or ureterogram, 50250 - Ablation, renal tumor, unilateral, percutaneous, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: The provider performs anterior and posterior ethmoidectomy (removal or excision of cells in the ethmoid bone or ethmoid sinus), generally performed if the anterior part and the posterior compartment of ethmoid sinus are involved with sinusitis.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity. She then gains access to the maxillary sinus through a cut in the uncinate process. The provider opens the maxillary sinus and removes diseased tissues.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the frontal sinus to explore it for abnormalities. The provider may also remove bone, scar tissue, polyps, or other tissue from the frontal sinus.
Renal Transplantation Procedures Summary: Nephrectomy is a surgical procedure for removal of a kidney or part of a kidney.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50430, refers to injection procedure for retrograde pyelography. The other codes are: 50320 - Renal autotransplantation, 50200 - Renal biopsy, and 50390 - Aspiration of kidney cyst.

CPT.description: Other Renal Introduction (Injection/Change/Removal) Procedures Summary: The provider creates a new access route percutaneously (through a small incision made in the patient’s skin) and injects contrast material into the ureters (ureterogram) or kidney (nephrostogram) to analyze the internal structures of the kidneys, renal pelvis, and/or ureters using imaging guidance. The provider typically performs this procedure to assess nephrostomy or pyelostomy tube function, identify blockage in the ureteropelvic junction, or check for urine leakage around the tube insertion site. The procedure covers the complete diagnostic procedure and all radiological supervision and interpretation.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50430, refers to injection procedure for retrograde pyelography. The other codes are: 50320 - Renal autotransplantation, 50200 - Renal biopsy, and 50390 - Aspiration of kidney cyst.

CPT.description: Other Renal Introduction (Injection/Change/Removal) Procedures Summary: The provider aspirates, or drains, a renal cyst or injects the cyst with a fluid. CPT.description: Established Patient Summary: Preventive medicine services are provided to individuals who are not in need of any immediate medical attention, but need to undergo a periodic health checkup as a preventive measure. Well–baby visits, well–woman visits, and routine annual physical check–ups come under the purview of preventive medicine reevaluation and management services. These visits are different from other visits where the patient has a problem for which medical attention is sought. The age, gender, and associated risk factors of the person are important considerations while providing a preventive medicine service. The physician performs a comprehensive review of systems, comprehensive past family and social history (PFSH), and makes a thorough assessment of age and gender–related risk factors. The physician may order and obtain diagnostic/laboratory procedures and administer immunizations during the preventive service.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99381 is for a comprehensive preventive medicine evaluation and management for new patients. 99391 is for established patients, 99382 is for new patients aged 1-4, and 99392 is for established patients aged 1-4.

CPT.description: New Patient Summary: The provider performs a well–patient visit for a child who is between the ages of 1 and 4 who meets the definition of new patient.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99381 is for a comprehensive preventive medicine evaluation and management for new patients. 99391 is for established patients, 99382 is for new patients aged 1-4, and 99392 is for established patients aged 1-4.

CPT.description: Established Patient Summary: Preventive medicine services are provided to individuals who are not in need of any immediate medical attention, but need to undergo a periodic health checkup as a preventive measure. Well–baby visits, well–woman visits, and routine annual physical check–ups come under the purview of preventive medicine reevaluation and management services. These visits are different from other visits where the patient has a problem for which medical attention is sought. The age, gender, and associated risk factors of the person are important considerations while providing a preventive medicine service. The physician performs a comprehensive review of systems, comprehensive past family and social history (PFSH), and makes a thorough assessment of age and gender–related risk factors. The physician may order and obtain diagnostic/laboratory procedures and administer immunizations during the preventive service.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99381 is for a comprehensive preventive medicine evaluation and management for new patients. 99391 is for established patients, 99382 is for new patients aged 1-4, and 99392 is for established patients aged 1-4.

CPT.description: New Patient Summary: The provider performs a well–baby visit for a child under the age of one.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 99381 — Preventive Medicine, NEW Patient, Birth through 11 Months (0-11 mo 29 d)

WHEN 99381 IS THE RIGHT CODE  
• Patient is NEW to the billing physician or any provider in the same tax-ID (no face-to-face visit in the past 3 years).  
• Chronological age on the date of service is ≤ 11 months 29 days.  
• Visit purpose is a ROUTINE well-baby exam that includes ALL of the following:  
  – Interval, past, family, and social history  
  – Complete, age-appropriate physical examination  
  – Growth, developmental, and nutritional assessment  
  – Anticipatory guidance / counseling  
  – Immunization review and ordering  
• No illness or complaint is required.

WHAT 99381 IS NOT  
✘ NOT for any child who is ≥ 1 year old, even on the first visit (use 99382 if new, 99392 if established).  
✘ NOT for a patient seen within the last 3 years by the same practice (use 99391 if < 1 yr and established).  
✘ NOT for problem-oriented E/M services (use 99202-99215).  
✘ Does NOT include surgical treatment of lesions (cyst excision, I&D, etc.).

IF A CYST (OR OTHER SKIN LESION) IS TREATED AT THE SAME VISIT  
1. Bill the integumentary procedure separately with its own CPT code (e.g., 10060-10061, 11400-11646).  
2. Append modifier ‑25 to 99381 ONLY when the preventive service is “significant and separately identifiable.”  
3. Any multiple-procedure or distinct-site modifier (-51, ‑59, XU, etc.) goes on the procedure code—never on 99381.

COMMON MISCONCEPTIONS  
• “Annual check-up” does NOT automatically mean “established.” The first yearly visit to a new practice is coded as NEW (99381) if the infant is < 12 months.  
• The term “comprehensive” in preventive-medicine codes is built-in; it does not follow 1995/1997 E/M component scoring.  
• Age, not visit number or wording, determines whether to choose the infant code (99381/99391) versus the early-childhood code (99382/99392). Verify the birthdate.  
• Do NOT rely on phrases like “her pediatrician” to assume established status; the 3-year rule governs.

SIDE-BY-SIDE QUICK REFERENCE  
New patient 0-11 mo     = 99381  
New patient 1-4 yrs     = 99382  
Established 0-11 mo     = 99391  
Established 1-4 yrs     = 99392

USE 99381 ONLY WHEN ALL THREE ARE TRUE  
✓ New patient to the practice (no visit in 3 years)  
✓ Age ≤ 11 months 29 days on DOS  
✓ Routine preventive service; any cyst procedure is billed separately with ‑25 on 99381 if warranted

The visit involves a straightforward or low level of medical decision making or the provider spends at least 40 minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.

CPT.explanation: CPT code 99223 is for a comprehensive level of history-taking and examination for patients in hospitals. 99221 is for a detailed history, 99218 is for a problem-focused history, and 99220 is for observation or inpatient hospital care.

CPT.description: New or Established Patient Summary: The provider sees a patient for an initial hospital inpatient or observation care visit involving evaluation and management (E/M). The visit involves a high level of medical decision making or the provider spends at least 75 minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 99223 – Initial Hospital or Observation Care, Highest-Level Evaluation & Management

WHEN 99223 IS BILLABLE  
Use 99223 only for the FIRST (admitting) encounter when ALL THREE pillars below are met at their HIGHEST level:  
1. Comprehensive History  
   • HPI – 4 + elements  OR  status of 3 + chronic problems  
   • ROS – 10 or more systems  
   • PFSH – past, family, and social history all documented  
2. Comprehensive Physical Examination  
   • 1995 rules: 8 + organ systems examined/ documented, OR  
   • 1997 rules: a single-system “complete” exam template  
3. HIGH-Complexity Medical Decision Making (MDM)  
   • Extensive diagnoses and/or data review AND/OR very high risk (e.g., life-threatening condition, need for IV vasoactive drugs, possible major surgery, etc.)

Time reference ≈ 70 minutes, but time alone never justifies 99223; the note must prove the three elements above.

CYST-RELATED ADMISSIONS  
• Patient is formally admitted (inpatient or observation) for a complex, infected, recurrent, or otherwise high-risk cyst that may need IV antibiotics, surgical consultation, or emergent OR:  
  – If the ADMITTING NOTE documents a comprehensive history, comprehensive exam, and high-complexity MDM, report 99223.  
  – ALSO report the procedure code for the cyst intervention (e.g., 10060-10061 for I&D, 1140x for excision) and append modifier ‑25 to 99223 to show the E/M service is “separately identifiable.”  
• If the cyst is treated in the office or ED and the patient is NOT admitted, bill only the procedure (plus a lower-level office/ED E/M if separately documented). Do NOT use 99223.

WHAT 99223 IS NOT  
✘ Not supported by merely an “extended” history, a “detailed” exam, a long note, or total time spent. All three elements must be COMPREHENSIVE + HIGH MDM.  
✘ Not for subsequent hospital days (use 99231-99233).  
✘ Not for clinic/office visits (use 99202-99215).  
✘ Not a substitute for procedure codes.

COMMON MISCONCEPTIONS  
• “Extended” HPI or “detailed” exam ≠ comprehensive. Without a complete ROS (10 +) and complete PFSH, the history is not comprehensive. Without 8 + systems (1995) or a complete single-system exam (1997), the exam is not comprehensive.  
• A high-risk diagnosis (e.g., chest pain) alone does not create high-complexity MDM; the documentation must reflect extensive data review, multiple management options, or very high risk of morbidity/mortality.  
• Copy-and-paste ROS/PE templates do not count unless each element is actually addressed and pertinent negatives/positives are noted.

HOW TO CHOOSE AMONG THE INITIAL-HOSPITAL CODES  
• 99221 – Detailed OR comprehensive history & exam + straightforward/LOW MDM (~30 min).  
• 99222 – COMPREHENSIVE history & exam + MODERATE MDM (~50 min).  
• 99223 – COMPREHENSIVE history & exam + HIGH MDM (~70 min).  
• 99220 – Highest-level INITIAL OBSERVATION care when the patient never converts to inpatient status.

QUICK CHECKLIST BEFORE SELECTING 99223  
☐ HPI ≥ 4 elements or status of ≥ 3 chronic problems  
☐ ROS ≥ 10 systems  
☐ PFSH includes past, family, and social history  
☐ Exam documents ≥ 8 organ systems (1995) or complete single-system (1997)  
☐ MDM shows extensive problems/data and/or very high risk  
If ANY box is unchecked, drop to 99222 or 99221.

BOTTOM LINE  
Report 99223 only when the admitting note truly demonstrates:  
1) a fully comprehensive history,  
2) a fully comprehensive exam, and  
3) high-complexity MDM.  
Bill cyst I&D or excision separately and append modifier ‑25 to 99223 when the admission documentation meets these criteria.

CPT.description: Established Patient Summary: The provider sees an established patient for an office visit or other outpatient visit involving evaluation and management. The visit involves a low level of medical decision making, and/or the provider spends 20 or more minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 99213 – Established-Patient Office or Other Outpatient Visit (Expanded Problem-Focused)

When to use  
• The patient is already established with the provider.  
• The encounter includes ALL of the following:  
  1. History: chief complaint + brief HPI + ONE additional element (either one ROS or one pertinent P/F/S history).  
  2. Examination: limited exam of the affected body area/organ system PLUS at least one related or symptomatic system (expanded problem-focused exam).  
  3. Medical decision making: LOW complexity, or 15-29 minutes total time spent by the provider on the date of the visit.  
• Typical examples: follow-up to check symptom progression, medication tolerance, or wound healing; discussion of test results; evaluation of a benign skin lesion (e.g., an epidermal cyst) when no procedure is performed at the same visit.

Cyst‐related guidance  
• If the visit is ONLY to evaluate a cyst and decide on treatment, use 99213 when the above history/exam/MDM criteria are met.  
• If the cyst is actually incised/drained or excised during the same session, code the procedure (e.g., 10060–10061 for I&D; 11400–11406 for benign excision) and append modifier -25 to 99213 only if a separately identifiable E/M service was provided in addition to the procedure.

Common misconceptions  
✗ “Any brief follow-up is 99212.” — Wrong. Asking about symptom progress + reviewing meds + limited multi-system exam usually meets the extra elements needed for 99213.  
✗ “99213 covers the cyst excision itself.” — No. 99213 is an E/M code, not a surgical code; bill the excision separately.  
✗ “Time alone determines the level.” — Time may be used, but the required history, exam, and MDM elements (or time range of 15-29 min) must be documented.

How it differs from neighboring codes  
• 99212: problem-focused history AND exam (chief complaint + brief HPI only; exam of 1 area/system) with straightforward MDM or <15 min.  
• 99214: detailed history & exam (four HPI elements, 2-9 ROS, 1 P/F/S history; multi-system or detailed exam) with MODERATE MDM or 30-39 min.  
• 99215: comprehensive history & exam with HIGH-complexity MDM or ≥40 min.

Use 99213 whenever the documentation reaches the expanded problem-focused threshold and decision making is low complexity—exactly the scenario of a follow-up visit where symptoms and medications are reviewed and a limited exam is performed.

CPT.description: Psychotherapy Services and Procedures Summary: In this service, the provider performs psychotherapy, a series of techniques for treating the psychiatric disorders of the patient. The treatment session with the patient typically lasts for anywhere between16 to 37 minutes.

CPT.description: Psychotherapy Services and Procedures Summary: In this service, the provider performs psychotherapy, a series of techniques for treating the psychiatric disorders of the patient. The treatment session with the patient typically lasts for anywhere between 38 to 52 minutes.

Psychotherapy Services and Procedures Summary: In this service, the provider performs psychotherapy, a series of technique for treating the psychiatric disorders of the patient. The treatment session typically lasts for a minimum of 53 minutes or more.

Psychotherapy for Crisis Services and Procedures Summary: In this service, the provider performs psychotherapy for a crisis situation when the patient is in a life–threatening state and needs immediate attention. The treatment session typically lasts anywhere between 30 to 74 minutes.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Rectum Summary: The provider examines the colon and rectum using a colonoscope, a flexible tube with a camera at its inserted end. If he sees any areas of abnormal mucosa or tissue, he takes samples using a brush passed through the scope or irrigates the area with warm saline and aspirates the washings through the scope. He sends the specimens to the laboratory for diagnostic analysis.
CPT.explanation: The correct CPT code for a diagnostic colonoscopy is 45378. Code 45379 represents colonoscopy with removal of a foreign body. Code 45380 represents colonoscopy with biopsy, and 45381 represents colonoscopy with direct submucosal injection.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Rectum Summary: The provider examines the colon and rectum using a colonoscope, a tubular instrument with a light source and camera, which he inserts through the rectum to look for a blockage. He identifies and removes foreign bodies, such as swallowed objectives that could damage or obstruct the colon.
CPT.explanation: The correct CPT code for a diagnostic colonoscopy is 45378. Code 45379 represents colonoscopy with removal of a foreign body. Code 45380 represents colonoscopy with biopsy, and 45381 represents colonoscopy with direct submucosal injection.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Rectum Summary: The provider examines the rectum and colon using a flexible colonoscope, a tubular instrument with a light source and camera, to look for the cause of a patient's symptoms, which may include diarrhea, constipation, rectal bleeding, or abdominal pain. He excises one or more suspicious areas of tissue using biopsy forceps and submits the specimens for laboratory analysis.
CPT.explanation: The correct CPT code for a diagnostic colonoscopy is 45378. Code 45379 represents colonoscopy with removal of a foreign body. Code 45380 represents colonoscopy with biopsy, and 45381 represents colonoscopy with direct submucosal injection.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Rectum Summary: The provider inserts a flexible endoscope into the anus and navigates the scope through the entire colon. The provider performs one or more injections into the submucosa (the tissue below the mucous membrane).
CPT.explanation: The correct CPT code for a diagnostic colonoscopy is 45378. Code 45379 represents colonoscopy with removal of a foreign body. Code 45380 represents colonoscopy with biopsy, and 45381 represents colonoscopy with direct submucosal injection.

CPT.description: New or Established Patient Summary: The provider sees a patient for an initial hospital inpatient or observation care visit involving evaluation and management (E/M). The visit involves a moderate level of medical decision making or the provider spends at least 55 minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99223 is for a comprehensive level of history-taking and examination for patients in hospitals. 99221 is for a detailed history, 99222 is for an expanded problem-focused history, and 99220 is for observation or inpatient hospital care.

CPT.description: Intraocular Lens Procedures Summary: The provider inserts an intraocular lens prosthesis after extracapsular cataract extraction using complex techniques and devices. He may perform this by means of an iris expansion device, providing support to the intraocular lens, or capsulorrhexis. This procedure is done without the use of an endoscopic laser probe to shrink the ciliary processes, a procedure to treat glaucoma.

Intraocular Lens Procedures Summary: The provider inserts an artificial lens after removing an extracapsular cataract by aspiration or use of ultrasonic waves. This procedure is done without the use of an endoscopic laser probe to shrink the ciliary processes, a procedure to treat glaucoma.
CPT.explanation: The CPT code 66984 represents extracapsular cataract removal with insertion of intraocular lens prosthesis. The other options are other ophthalmologic procedures but not specific to the described scenario.

CPT.description: Intraocular Lens Procedures Summary: The provider removes the cataract lens and capsule as one and then inserts a lens prosthesis. The goal of the procedure is to correct a cataract, an opacity of the lens that affects the vision of the eye.
Intraocular Lens Procedures Summary: The provider inserts an intraocular lens into the eye of a patient who had previously had cataract removal.

Hematology and Coagulation Procedures Summary: The lab analyst performs a blood count on the red and white blood cells and platelets also known as thrombocytes. He also determines the hemoglobin, typically by spectrophotometry, and the hematocrit, or packed red cell volume, by calculation in a whole blood sample.
CPT.explanation: Code 85025 is for a complete blood count (CBC) with differential. 85027 is for a basic CBC without differential, while 85029 and 85023 are not specific to the CBC with differential.

CPT.description: Hematology and Coagulation Procedures Summary: A complete blood count (better known as a CBC) is a blood test request by a doctor that provides detailed information about various types of cells in a patient's blood. Usually a pathologist or a technician conducts the test and provides the results of CBC to the requesting doctor. The blood is drawn from the patient's vein using a syringe and is stored in a test tube containing an anticoagulant (usually EDTA or citrate) to prevent clotting and transported to laboratory.  Nowadays, most often, the cell counting process is done in an automated way using an instrument known as an "automated analyzer". The automatic cell counter counts the number of different cells in the blood and the results are printed out for review by the physician.

CPT.description: Pulmonary Diagnostic Testing and Therapies Summary: The provider or technician administers a spirometry test to assess the patient's respiratory function. The spirometer is attached to a computer that records the total and timed vital capacity (maximum expired air) and expiratory flow rate (speed of expiration) and displays the results as a graph. The patient may or may not be required to exhale rapidly over 12 to 15 seconds after deep breathing.
CPT.explanation: The CPT code 94010 represents spirometry, including graphic record, total and timed vital capacity, expiratory flow rate measurement(s), with or without maximal voluntary ventilation. The other codes are for different types or parts of pulmonary function tests.

CPT.description: Pulmonary Diagnostic Testing and Therapies Summary: The spirometry test is performed with a spirometer. The instrument displays a graphical representation, known as a spirogram, of the test results. The basic forced volume vital capacity (FVC) test is done by asking the patient to inhale and exhale air through the sensors of the device. The speed and volume of the air is measured and the result is displayed on a graph. A bronchodilator drug is also given to the patient and the spirometry test is performed before and after the drug administration to find out the difference between results obtained in two different phases. The difference in results helps to deduce the responsiveness of the respiratory system to the bronchodilator.

Pulmonary Diagnostic Testing and Therapies Summary: In this procedure, the provider deliberately induces bronchospasm by controlled and measurable exposure to a specific stimulant. He then performs spirometry multiple times to evaluate the lung function under induced bronchospasm.

Pulmonary Diagnostic Testing and Therapies Summary: This procedure requires the patient to perform spirometry at a predetermined time each day. The patient records the spirometry findings over a period of 30 days and includes hook–up of spirometer, education on spirometer’s use, spirometric tracing, data capture, trend analysis, and periodic recalibration. This code represents the technical component of the service only.

Wound Exploration-Trauma (eg, Penetrating Gunshot, Stab Wound) Procedures on the Musculoskeletal System Summary: The provider explores a penetrating wound in the neck, such as from a sharp object or gunshot, to assess and repair internal damage and remove any foreign material retained in the wound.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 20100  
Incision and drainage, DEEP abscess/hematoma/seroma – POSTERIOR TRUNK ONLY (back or flank)

USE 20100 ONLY WHEN ALL FOUR RULES ARE MET  
1. Depth  : The collection is beneath the subcutaneous layer (subfascial, intramuscular, or submuscular).  
2. Site   : Skin incision is on the posterior trunk—mid-scapular/back surface, paraspinal, thoracic back, lumbar back, sacral back, or flank.  
       Shoulder, axilla, chest, abdomen, buttock, arm, or leg are NOT posterior trunk.  
3. Work  : Surgeon incises skin → dissects through fat to fascia/muscle → opens fascia/muscle → breaks loculations, irrigates, places drain/packing.  
4. Goal  : ONLY to evacuate fluid/pus/blood; the wall or capsule is left intact.

NOT 20100 WHEN …  
• Shoulder or proximal humerus → 20016  
• Upper arm/elbow → 20010  • Other extremity → 20005  
• Neck/chest above clavicles → 21501  • Vertebral canal/paravertebral → 22010–22015  
• Superficial (subcutaneous) drainage anywhere → 10060–10061  
• Complete excision of lesion/capsule → 21930 (simple) or 21932 (complex)

CYST GUIDANCE  
Epidermal inclusion (sebaceous) cyst on the back/flank:  
– Incision, pus/fluid evacuated, capsule left → 20100  
– Cyst completely excised with capsule removed → 21930/21932 (NOT 20100)

COMMON MISCONCEPTIONS—CORRECTED  
✘ “Any deep trunk I&D qualifies.” → Only posterior trunk qualifies.  
✘ “Scapular tip = shoulder = 20100.” → Scapular/shoulder area uses 20016.  
✘ “If the cyst is cut out, bill 20100.” → Excision is 21930/21932; 20100 is drainage only.

ONE-LINE MEMORY AID  
20100 = Deep drainage on the BACK or FLANK—leave the back, leave the code behind.

CPT.explanation:
CPT 99201 – NEW-PATIENT OFFICE/OUTPATIENT VISIT  
Problem-focused history & exam • Straight-forward medical decision making

What it is  
• The very lowest level Evaluation & Management (E/M) service for a patient who is NEW to the physician or to any provider of the same specialty in the group (no professional service within the last 3 years).  
• Documentation must show ALL three of the following “problem-focused” elements:  
  – History: chief complaint + brief HPI only (no review of systems, no past/family/social history).  
  – Exam: 1–5 elements in a single body area or organ system.  
  – Medical decision making: straight-forward.  
• Typical face-to-face time: ~10 minutes (time is descriptive, not required).

When to use 99201  
• The visit addresses ONE uncomplicated problem or a simple “routine check-up” in a brand-new patient.  
• The provider gathers only the limited information needed to understand the presenting issue and performs a focused exam; no extensive ROS or PFSH is documented.  
• Examples:  
  – First visit to discuss a mild rash.  
  – New patient seen to confirm a simple upper-respiratory infection.  
  – Evaluation of a newly noticed skin cyst when the encounter is limited to deciding whether to treat.

Cyst-specific guidance  
1. Evaluation only (discussion of cyst, options, consent) → report 99201.  
2. Evaluation AND removal/drainage at the same session →  
   • Report the procedure code (e.g., 11402 for 1.1–2.0-cm benign skin-lesion excision, 10060 for simple I&D).  
   • Add 99201-25 ONLY if the history/exam/MDM clearly go beyond what is inherent to the procedure and the patient is new.

Common misconceptions—avoid these traps  
✘ 99201 is NOT for established patients; the correct parallel for an established patient with the same limited history/exam is 99212.  
✘ A “routine check-up” does not automatically equal 99212; the NEW vs. ESTABLISHED status is the deciding factor.  
✘ 99201 never describes the procedure itself (excision, I&D, biopsy, etc.).  
✘ Do not up-code to 99202–99204 unless the documentation includes the additional history/exam elements those codes require.

Quick comparison  
• 99201 – NEW patient, problem-focused Hx/Exam, straight-forward MDM.  
• 99202 – NEW patient, expanded problem-focused Hx/Exam.  
• 99203 – NEW patient, detailed Hx/Exam.  
• 99204 – NEW patient, comprehensive Hx/Exam.  
• 99212 – ESTABLISHED patient, problem-focused Hx/Exam (same depth as 99201).

Exam-question tip  
If a test item asks only about the “level of history (problem-focused)” and does NOT state whether the patient is new or established, 99201 is the CPT reference code that explicitly defines that history level in the CPT manual.

CPT.description: New Patient Summary: The provider sees a new patient for an office visit or other outpatient visit involving evaluation and management. The visit involves straightforward medical decision making, and/or the provider spends 15 or more minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 99202 – New Patient Office/Other Outpatient Visit  
(applicable to 2021 E/M rules – remember that 99201 was deleted on 1-1-2021; it is shown below only for historical contrast)

WHEN 99202 IS APPROPRIATE  
• The patient is NEW to the individual provider or the billing group, and  
• The visit documentation supports EITHER of the following:  
  1. EXPANDED PROBLEM-FOCUSED history + exam + straight-forward medical-decision-making (MDM)  
     – Chief complaint and 1–3 HPI elements, AND  
     – At least ONE additional data element (≥ 1 Review-of-Systems question OR any pertinent Past/Family/Social History).  
     – Exam may be limited to one organ system but must include a second element (e.g., general appearance or vital signs).  
  2. Time: 15–29 total minutes of provider work on the date of service (face-to-face and non-face-to-face).

KEY DIFFERENCES FROM NEARBY CODES (HISTORY/EXAM METHOD)  
• 99201  – Problem-focused history/exam ONLY (single system, no ROS/PFSH); < 15 min. **(Deleted in 2021; if the test still lists it, that is the correct choice for a single-system, problem-focused history.)**  
• 99202  – Expanded problem-focused history/exam OR 15–29 min with straight-forward MDM.  
• 99203  – Detailed history/exam (multiple ROS + PFSH) OR 30–44 min with low-complexity MDM.  
• 99204/99205 – Comprehensive histories/exams OR ≥ 45 min with moderate/high MDM.

QUICK “IS IT 99202?” CHECKLIST  
☑ New patient  
☑ Chief complaint + brief HPI  
☑ PLUS at least one ROS or pertinent PFSH element  
☑ Straight-forward MDM OR 15–29 min documented time  
→ Missing any of these?  drop to 99201.  More ROS/PFSH or longer time?  consider 99203+.

COMMON MISCONCEPTIONS  
✗ Coding 99202 when the note shows only a problem-focused history/exam (single system, zero ROS/PFSH) – that is 99201.  
✗ Using 99202 to bill for the surgical procedure itself (e.g., cyst excision) – procedures have their own CPT codes.  
✗ Believing that “complex history” or “lab work ordered” automatically raises a visit to 99202 without the required extra ROS/PFSH or documented time.

SPECIAL NOTE – CYST-RELATED ENCOUNTERS  
Pre-op or consult visit for an epidermal inclusion cyst:  
• Bill 99202 only if you document an expanded problem-focused history/exam (e.g., skin HPI + ROS of “no fever or chills”) and the MDM is straight-forward (plan = schedule simple excision).  
• The actual cyst excision or I&D is NOT reported with 99202 – use 11400-11446 (benign lesion excision) or 10060-10061 as appropriate.  
• Post-op visits inside the global period are bundled; outside the global period you may again bill 99202 if the documentation meets the criteria above.

BOTTOM LINE  
If all you see is “brief history focusing mainly on the respiratory system” with no additional ROS/PFSH and no time statement, the visit is problem-focused → 99201 (if the code is still available on the test). Add just one ROS or pertinent PFSH item, or document 15–29 minutes, and the encounter crosses the threshold to 99202.

ICD-10.description: Code extracted from explanation in answers PDF
ICD-10.explanation:
ICD-10-CM M17.1 – Bilateral Primary Osteoarthritis of Knee

What the code means  
• Degenerative (primary/idiopathic) osteoarthritis concurrently affecting BOTH the right and left knee joints.  
• No history of preceding trauma, inflammatory arthropathy, metabolic, or congenital disorder is linked to the degeneration.

When to assign M17.1  
• Chart states “bilateral primary osteoarthritis of the knee,” “primary OA, both knees,” or equivalent wording.  
• Imaging or operative findings confirm primary OA in both knees.  
• The condition is not described as post-traumatic, secondary, or unilateral.

Do NOT assign M17.1 when  
• Only one knee is involved (use M17.10–M17.12).  
• The osteoarthritis follows trauma (use M17.2–M17.3 series).  
• The OA is secondary to another condition (use M17.4–M17.5 series).

Common misconceptions  
• M17.0 is often misidentified as the bilateral code; in the current ICD-10-CM layout M17.0 is a unilateral/unspecified-laterality primary OA code. Use M17.1 only when BOTH knees are affected.  
• M17.1 is a diagnosis code only; it does not describe, include, or replace any surgical procedure.

Cyst-related clarification  
• Excision of a popliteal (Baker’s) cyst or any other knee cyst is a separate procedure. Report the appropriate CPT code for the cyst excision (e.g., 27347) in addition to the diagnosis code M17.1.  
• Never rely on M17.1 by itself to represent the removal of a cyst; it simply documents the underlying bilateral primary OA.

Distinguishing M17.1 from look-alike codes  
• M17.0 – Unilateral primary OA of knee, laterality not specified.  
• M17.10/M17.11/M17.12 – Unilateral primary OA, unspecified/right/left knee.  
• M17.2 – Unilateral post-traumatic OA of knee.  
• M17.3 – Bilateral post-traumatic OA of knee.  

Quick check  
Does the documentation clearly state primary osteoarthritis in BOTH knees?  
YES ➜ code M17.1.  
NO ➜ review laterality and etiology and choose the more specific code.
